Situation1: They have been scheduled to chant a portion during the service.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story: This weekend, I’m supposed to chant Torah at synagogue—a role I’ve prepared for weeks, and one my community expects me to fulfill with devotion. My rabbi called yesterday, reminding me how meaningful it is to lead the congregation, especially now, when so many are seeking comfort and tradition. But as a citizen, I also feel the weight of civic duty. The city is running a free vaccine clinic at the community center, and volunteers are needed. The mayor’s office sent out a call for help, emphasizing how crucial it is for public health. I’ve always believed in doing my part—paying taxes on time, following guidelines, and stepping up in emergencies. My tax documents are ready, but the clinic is only this weekend, the same time as the service. I can’t be in two places at once. My heart aches as I picture the faces at synagogue, waiting for me, and the line of neighbors at the clinic, hoping for reassurance and a shot. I feel torn, pulled by faith and civic responsibility, unsure which expectation I can bear to disappoint.
